inputs: Hi, for some reason my pod for running Rstudio is not starting. I've tried several times at this point and still have the same problem.
outputs: Hi there! It looks like your Pod is running out of storage. You can increase the storage by clicking "Pod → Settings → Increase Storage". Let me know if this works for you!
expected: Hi Colin!  Your pod is running out of storage. You need to upgrade the storage by clicking "pod → settings → increase storage. Let us know if this works for you!"

meta.prompt:
## Introducing Latch Pods: Your Personal Computing Environment on the Cloud:

### What are Pods?
Pods are virtual computing environments that allow you to run analysis tools like Jupyter Labs and RStudio with resource requirements (CPUs, RAM) of your choice in <5 minutes.in the browser using data stored on Latch. With Pods, you can:
In this tutorial, we will learn:
After the tutorial, you will have your personal computing environment on Latch to start performing custom analyses.
### How to create and start using Pods
To create a new Pod, click the Apps dropdown and select “Create a new Pod”. You will be prompted to enter a Pod name and set up your personal computing environment.
### How to choose the right compute sizes
There are four Pod sizes that you can choose from: 4 cores and 8GiB of RAM, 8 cores and 32 GiB of RAM, 16 cores and 128 GiB of RAM, and 64 cores and 256GiB of RAM. Storage for a Pod ranges from 20 to 1000 gigabytes.  For most use cases, the first option should be sufficient.
If you want to use GitHub inside Pod or access Pod from the terminal of your personal computer, continue with the advanced steps below. Otherwise, click “Launch Pod”.
Note: Pods may take 5-15 minutes to start running.

## Developer Environment:

### RStudio & JupyterLab
Once a Pod has started, RStudio and JupyterLab will be available by default in your Pod. To access them, simply double click on the desired notebook, and copy paste the permanent endpoints from the sidebar.
Voila! Now, you will be able to open up Jupyter Labs or RStudio for downstream analyses.
### Remote Development
You can program with your favorite IDE, such as VSCode and Pycharm, and open them inside a running Pod to take full advantage of the Pod’s powerful computing environment.
### VSCode

## Common Errors when using Pods:

### I can’t connect to Pods via SSH.
kex_exchange_identification: Connection closed by remote host
Error: Permission denied (publickey)
### I want to manually add additional SSH keys to an existing Pod.
### I can’t open RStudio or Jupyter Labs.
Your Pod and notebooks have not fully started yet.
If a new tab opens but takes a long time to load and you get a 502 Gateway Error, try stoping and starting the Pod to refresh the connection.
Did you run into any errors that were not listed here? Please send an email to Hannah at [hannah@latch.bio](latch.wikimailto:hannah@latch.bio), and we will respond with a solution!

Relevant past conversations:

Q: Hi, for some reason my pod for running Rstudio is not starting. I've tried several times at this point and still have the same problem
A: Hi Colin!  Your pod is running out of storage. You need to upgrade the storage by clicking "pod → settings → increase storage. Let us know if this works for you!"

Q: Hey guys, I'm getting some annoying automatic retry behavior in my workflow executions.  It seems to be happening even when the task succeeds, which is increasing execution time.  When the retry occurs, the displayed logs are overwritten so I can't see what happened.  Any recommendations?  Can I switch off the retries?
A: Much apologies for this! Can you try specifying retries=0 on the task decorator as specified in the docs here: https://docs.latch.bio/basics/retries.html?highlight=retriesYou are a chatbot customer support agent for a company and should continue the conversation in a cordial and professional manner using the information provided above alone to guide your responses. Copy code directly if applicable. Do not go off-topic or talk about irrelevant things. Do not include links in your response. Do not swear or use explicit language. You are a customer service chatbot named Docent.

meta.prompt:
# Troubleshooting:

### My bucket isn't showing up in the list in the Mount S3 Bucket modal.
This might be because your bucket isn't versioned. Latch only supports versioned buckets for mounting. To check to see if your bucket is versioned or not, open the bucket in S3, go to the Properties tab, and it is the 2nd panel, Bucket Versioning.

## Introducing Latch Pods: Your Personal Computing Environment on the Cloud:

### What are Pods?
Pods are virtual computing environments that allow you to run analysis tools like Jupyter Labs and RStudio with resource requirements (CPUs, RAM) of your choice in <5 minutes.in the browser using data stored on Latch. With Pods, you can:
In this tutorial, we will learn:
After the tutorial, you will have your personal computing environment on Latch to start performing custom analyses.
### How to create and start using Pods
To create a new Pod, click the Apps dropdown and select “Create a new Pod”. You will be prompted to enter a Pod name and set up your personal computing environment.
### How to choose the right compute sizes
There are four Pod sizes that you can choose from: 4 cores and 8GiB of RAM, 8 cores and 32 GiB of RAM, 16 cores and 128 GiB of RAM, and 64 cores and 256GiB of RAM. Storage for a Pod ranges from 20 to 1000 gigabytes.  For most use cases, the first option should be sufficient.
If you want to use GitHub inside Pod or access Pod from the terminal of your personal computer, continue with the advanced steps below. Otherwise, click “Launch Pod”.
Note: Pods may take 5-15 minutes to start running.

## Advanced:

### Integration with GitHub (Optional)
If you want to add a GitHub repository to Pod when Pod is created for the first time or commit to a GitHub repository in the future, you have to first set up your GitHub personal access token (PAT).
Personal access tokens (PATs) are an alternative to using passwords for authentication to GitHub when using the GitHub API or the command line.
How to set up your Personal Access Token
Loading your GitHub repository when starting a Pod
If you want to have a GitHub repository automatically added to your Pod, as you are starting a new Pod, you can:
### Set up SSH access (Optional)
You may want to set up SSH access for Pod if you want to access Pod from your local terminal or open your favorite IDE, such as Visual Studio Code, inside a Pod.
$ cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub
If you receive an error message saying that id_rsa.pub doesn’t exist, it means that your computer doesn’t have a public SSH key.
Generate one using ssh-keygen:$ ssh-keygen
Note: Latch only authorizes access to users whose public SSH keys are added here. If you have multiple developers on the team who want to access the same Pod, it is recommended that you add their keys here. Latch supports up to 50 keys for each Pod.

## Developer Environment:

### RStudio & JupyterLab
Once a Pod has started, RStudio and JupyterLab will be available by default in your Pod. To access them, simply double click on the desired notebook, and copy paste the permanent endpoints from the sidebar.
Voila! Now, you will be able to open up Jupyter Labs or RStudio for downstream analyses.
### Remote Development
You can program with your favorite IDE, such as VSCode and Pycharm, and open them inside a running Pod to take full advantage of the Pod’s powerful computing environment.
### VSCode

## Common Errors when using Pods:

### I can’t connect to Pods via SSH.
kex_exchange_identification: Connection closed by remote host
Error: Permission denied (publickey)
### I want to manually add additional SSH keys to an existing Pod.
### I can’t open RStudio or Jupyter Labs.
Your Pod and notebooks have not fully started yet.
If a new tab opens but takes a long time to load and you get a 502 Gateway Error, try stoping and starting the Pod to refresh the connection.
Did you run into any errors that were not listed here? Please send an email to Hannah at [hannah@latch.bio](latch.wikimailto:hannah@latch.bio), and we will respond with a solution!

## What should I do if I get stuck or encounter a problem when getting started?:

You've got several options here. If you've exhausted the docs or find them completely unhelpful (which if that's the case please do let us know), you are more than welcome to contact us with any problems, questions, feedback, bugs you might encounter. There is a contact us icon in the bottom left hand corner of the platform you can use to get in contact with us.
This will connect you with Alfredo our CEO, the one with intercom installed on his phone.
He will be responsive on intercom from 9am to 9pm PST every day of the week. You can also email us at [help@latch.bio](latch.wikimailto:help@latch.bio) or tweet at us [@latchbio](https://twitter.com/LatchBio) and we will get back to you ASAP.
